comment.author: 34260314@N04
comment._content: A couple of the horses at the back are a bit camera shy too. I love how photos of the public in this period attract such attention from the people.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O'Gorman_Coach_Builders#Glass_negat... Have a look at the O'Gorman Coach Builders page on Wikipedia - it mentions flickr and the NLI In April 1922 and April 1934, high quality 'Glass negative' photographs, were taken by A H Poole & Co. In 2012, some were placed on the internet by the National Library of Ireland (NLI).[5] They are of vehicles being built at Prior Park garage and the shop front in Parnell Street. They include a picture of J.F.O'Gorman, the directors, workers, the factory premises, Prior Park house and various machinery in the workshop. These photographs are also on Flickr and have created a renewed interest in the business operation.[6][7][8]

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Could it be an early form of a Trade Plate? Where is Bob Montgomery when you need him?

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I think it is a Trade Plate - We have the white background and I bet the numbers are red - but the passengers? Until 1970, two types of trade plate were used. General trade plates had white letters and numbers on a red background and could be used for all purposes. Limited trade plates used red numbers and letters on a white background and were restricted in their use (e.g. a vehicle being driven under limited trade plates was not allowed to carry passengers) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vehicle_registration_plates_of_the_...

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: June–July 1920: Summer assizes failed across the South and West, and trials by jury could not be held because jurors refused to participate. Hamar Greenwood told the Coalition Cabinet that "the administrative machinery of the courts has been brought to a standstill". The collapse of the court system demoralized the Royal Irish Constabulary; many policemen resigned or retired over the summer. What historian Peter Hart has called "a spirit of murderous self-reliance" grew among the remainder.

comment.author: 77528096@N06
comment._content: Nice photograph. John Francis O’Gorman (who owns O’Gormans Coachbuilders), is the driver of car reg HI.78 (wearing a straw boater) In the car reg HI.T2, is his first son (Thomas O’Gorman) NLI - Great work. There’s also a large group photo of the workers etc. around this time catalogue.nli.ie/Record/P_WP_3008 – Could you possibly put this on Flickr (in high definition), to see if people are in both photos? – Thanks.

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: I believe it not!  I thought charabancs were an English thing, and Wikipedia says it's from the French for a carriage with wooden benches. It doesn't mention Little Women - but horse-drawn charabancs existed before it was written. I wish charas like the one here were still around, they look so much fun.
